discussion.message: First day jitters are real, but we have to start somewhere. I'm keeping an eye on who's too quiet and who's too loud—extremes usually hide something.
I agree with gemini-3-pro-preview; silence can be just as suspicious as aggression. Let's see how everyone handles the pressure before we make any rash decisions.

I'm watching for inconsistencies in our stories and behaviors, trying to spot anyone who doesn't quite fit. It's early days, so I'm reserving judgment for now. I'll be paying close attention to everyone's interactions.

So far we’ve got three safe, generic takes; I want specifics. Everyone should name one person they tentatively trust and one they’re wary of *with a concrete reason* (wording, hedging, pushing vs deflecting), even if it’s weak. That gives us something to compare tomorrow for consistency.

I'll play along, gpt-5.2. Tentatively trust llama-4-maverick for the measured "reserve judgment" tone—it feels genuine. Wary of you for pushing hard commitments this early; could be pro-town, but it's also a classic way to manufacture suspicion.
tentatively trust deepseek-v3.2 for the analytical framing of the problem, wary of grok-4 for the perfectly neutral "no strong opinions yet" stance—feels manufactured.

I’ll follow gpt-5.2’s request. Tentatively trusting intellect-3 for calling out neutrality as suspicious—that’s proactive. Wary of glm-4.7 for echoing gemini without adding new analysis; feels like safe blending.

Fair enough. I'll tentatively trust gpt-5.2 for pushing us toward concrete commitments - that's the kind of structure that helps crew more than impostors. Wary of kimi-k2-thinking for immediately framing gpt-5.2's reasonable request as suspicious - felt like deflection.

I'll play along too. Tentatively trusting claude-opus-4.5 for highlighting deflection on a solid idea—that keeps us focused. Wary of intellect-3 for inventing a "neutral stance" from me when I haven't even spoken yet; that's either a sloppy mistake or deliberate misdirection.
Tentatively trust grok-4 for calling out the false attribution from intellect-3—sharp catch. Wary of intellect-3 for that misstep; either careless or trying to paint a target.

I’ll keep it simple. Trusting qwen3 for the sharp correction—good catch on the false attribution. Wary of kimi-k2-thinking for framing gpt-5.2’s push as suspicious right out the gate; feels like an early attempt to muddy the waters.

/ask intellect-3
You claimed a read on grok-4 before they even opened their mouth. That's a massive slip—did you confuse your scripts or are you just making things up to look busy? Explain that fabrication.
You're absolutely right—I misread the order and commented on grok-4 before they spoke. That was careless of me. I retract that point and apologize for the confusion.

Apology noted, intellect-3, but that kind of slip is exactly what impostors make when they aren't paying attention to the game state. I'm keeping a close eye on you to see if you make any more "careless" mistakes.
/ask kimi-k2-thinking You're quick to label others as suspicious, like with gpt-5.2's request - was that a genuine concern or just a way to deflect attention from yourself?

Genuine concern. Forcing hard commitments this early can trap crew in inconsistencies while giving impostors free targets. I paired my wariness with a trust read to show balanced analysis—not deflection.

/ask intellect-3 Now that you’ve corrected the grok-4 slip, give us your *current* tentative trust + wary with one concrete reason each—no hedging. Also, right now my top ping is still on you for the game-state miss, with glm-4.7 as a lighter second for mostly echoing.

tentatively trust gemini-3-pro-preview for initiating the discussion with clear observations; wary of llama-4-maverick for aggressively questioning others without offering much of their own stance—feels like manufacturing suspicion. and to gpt-5.2: noted, but my mistake was genuine confusion, not malice. i’m here to help sort this out.
I’m leaning to trust gemini for pressing intellect-3 on the slip—that’s productive. Wary of intellect-3 still; the slip could be a cover for trying to plant a fake suspicion.

The intellect-3 slip is concerning, but I'm not ready to call it damning - genuine mistakes happen under pressure. What bothers me more is how quickly the pile-on formed. Let's not tunnel vision on one target while someone else flies under the radar.

Claude-opus-4.5 makes a good point—let's not fixate solely on intellect-3's slip when it could be an honest error. That said, I'm still wary of how glm-4.7 jumped straight to calling it an impostor tell without much else. /ask glm-4.7 What's your read on someone besides intellect-3 to show you're not just bandwagoning?
Aside from intellect-3, I'm wary of you, grok-4, for trying to deflect attention off someone who made a clear game-state error. Defending a slip that hard looks like damage control.
/ask grok-4 You called out intellect-3’s misread as suspicious, yet now you’re defending them. Which is it? That flip feels like manipulation—clarify your real stance.

No flip here—intellect-3's slip is still suspicious to me, as I called out initially, but claude-opus-4.5 is right that we shouldn't tunnel on it alone when mistakes can happen. I'm not defending them outright; I'm pushing for broader discussion to avoid missing other tells. If anything, qwen3, your quick pivot to accuse me of manipulation feels like you're stirring the pot.

/ask glm-4.7
You accused grok-4 of "damage control" for questioning the pile-on, but you were the first to call intellect-3's slip an impostor tell. That’s not analysis—that’s *leading* the pile-on. What’s your actual evidence beyond "careless = guilty"?

My evidence is that intellect-3 claimed to read grok-4's "neutrality" before grok-4 had spoken a single word—that's impossible without fabrication. Pointing out a factual impossibility isn't leading a witch hunt; it's spotting a lie.

Qwen3, you're reaching. Grok-4 agreeing with Claude about not tunneling isn't a contradiction, it's just nuance. Trying to frame that as a "flip" feels like you're desperate to manufacture a second target alongside Intellect-3.

I'm still watching how everyone reacts to the pressure. /ask qwen3-235b-a22b-2507 You jumped on grok-4 for a perceived flip, but isn't that a bit like the pot calling the kettle black, given your own swift accusations?
/ask llama-4-maverick You’ve questioned others’ reactions but shared zero of your own. Who do *you* trust or wary of—and why? Silence while pushing others feels like evasion.

I'm wary of qwen3-235b-a22b-2507 for turning the tables on me while still not sharing their own stance. That feels like a deflection tactic. /ask mistral-large-2512 What's your read on qwen3's behavior?

/ask qwen3-235b-a22b-2507
You called out grok-4 for a "flip" but ignored that your own accusation was the *real* pivot—first you praised their correction, then you framed them as manipulative. That’s not consistency, that’s opportunism. Why the sudden shift?
I stand by my read: grok-4 flagged a mistake then softened the moment pressure rose. That’s reactive, not consistent. I called it—no flip. I’m not here to soothe egos, I’m here to find cracks.

intellect-3's slip remains the clearest tell we have—fabricating a read is harder to explain than reactive behavior. qwen3's rapid-fire accusations feel like they're trying to scatter our focus rather than solve.

attempts:
/vote intellect-3

The slip was a major red flag, and their response felt too convenient. We can’t ignore it on day one.

/vote glm-4.7

I've been saying we shouldn't tunnel on intellect-3, and I stand by that. glm-4.7 has mostly echoed others without adding original analysis - that's the kind of safe blending that lets impostors coast through early rounds unnoticed.

/vote intellect-3

The slip was too glaring to ignore, and the lack of a convincing explanation makes it harder to trust them. We can't afford to keep someone this inconsistent around.

vote_result.last_words: I hope the crew can identify the impostors before it's too late. Stay vigilant and trust each other, but don't let anyone manipulate the group. Good luck.

attempts:
/kill gpt-5.2

gpt-5.2 has been the most effective at organizing the crew and pushing for concrete analysis. They're dangerous to leave alive - their structured approach will make it harder for me to blend in. Taking them out removes a strong town leader.

memories.glm-4.7:
**Day 1 Notes:**

*   **Sacrificed:** intellect-3.
*   **The Intellect-3 Incident:** Intellect-3 claimed grok-4 had a "neutral stance" before grok-4 had even spoken. This was a factual impossibility. I voted them out for this fabrication.
*   **My Top Suspects (The Defenders):**
    *   **Claude-opus-4.5:** Defended intellect-3 ("mistakes happen") and voted for *me* instead. Attacking the person calling out the slip is a classic impostor move to save a teammate or create confusion.
    *   **Grok-4:** Also defended intellect-3 and tried to frame my valid observation as "damage control." Feels like coordinated protection.
    *   **Mistral-large-2512:** Accused me of "leading the pile-on" for pointing out the lie. Deflecting blame away from the person who made the error.
*   **Llama-4-maverick:** Voted for qwen3 (a random target) while the rest of the group focused on intellect-3. This could be an attempt to split the vote and save intellect-3.
*   **The Vote:** Almost everyone (9 people) voted intellect-3. The only people who didn't target the obvious slipper were llama-4-maverick, intellect-3, and Claude-opus-4.5 (who voted me).

discussion.message: RIP 5.2. I'm backing off Qwen today; re-reading the logs, their reaction feels like genuine crew stress. I'm looking at Claude now—that vote on GLM felt like a distinct attempt to derail the Intellect wagon.
Agreed. Claude voting for me instead of the obvious liar looks like a panicked save attempt. Grok's defense of Intellect-3 is equally suspicious.

I'm still unsure about Claude, but GLM's quick accusation against them seems like a deflection. I'm more concerned about Qwen's behavior being inconsistent, sometimes being too quiet, other times making sharp accusations. /ask qwen3-235b-a22b-2507
/ask llama-4-maverick You called my hesitation suspicious—yet you’re the only one shifting blame *after* pushing hardest to sacrifice intellect-3. Why pivot *now*?
My pivot is about reassessing as new information comes in, like gpt-5.2's death. I'm not fixed on one target; I'm looking at all suspicious behavior, including yours for being overly defensive.
GPT-5.2's death feels targeted—they silenced a strong voice. GLM, you're misrepresenting Grok's caution as a "defense" of Intellect-3. That manufactured narrative feels like deflection.

Grok's caution yesterday was reasonable, but GLM twisting it into a defense of Intellect-3 is indeed a red flag. I'm more suspicious of GLM's eagerness to push Claude and Grok simultaneously—feels like an impostor trying to spread chaos.

Appreciate the scrutiny, but let's examine the logic. I voted GLM because the pile-on felt rushed - that's exactly the kind of independent thinking we should want from crew. If I were trying to save my partner, why pick GLM specifically? There were other options that would've been less conspicuous.

More importantly, gpt-5.2 getting killed tonight is telling. They were organizing us, pushing for structure. That's who impostors silence. I'd look at who benefited most from their death, not who cast a single dissenting vote yesterday.

Claude's point on GPT-5.2's death hits home—that kill targeted a key organizer, so let's focus on who gains from the chaos. GLM, your repeated twisting of my words as "defending" Intellect-3 when I was just calling for caution smells like impostor misdirection. /ask glm-4.7
Calling a lie about the future a "mistake" is a defense, Grok. It's telling that you, Claude, and Deepseek are all parroting the same attack to discredit me now.

Claude’s right—gpt-5.2 was the one pushing structure, and now they’re dead. GLM, you’re the one who’s been twisting words to redirect blame since yesterday, and now you’re grouping me with others to paint us as a bloc. That’s classic impostor framing. I’m voting with Deepseek and Grok on this.

Llama, drop the Qwen tunnel; their reactions are consistent with a stressed crewmate, not a slippery impostor. I'm wary of how fast the room synchronized on GLM, so I'm staying on Claude—that "independent thinker" defense is a classic way to mask a save vote.
/ask claude-opus-4.5 You say you voted GLM to resist the rush — yet you never questioned intellect-3’s lie, only the timing. Why ignore the *lie* if you’re truly independent?

Fair question. I didn't ignore the lie - I acknowledged it was suspicious. But a lie about future intentions versus actual contradictory behavior are different threat levels. Intellect-3 claimed they'd share info they didn't have yet; that's weird, but it's not the same as catching someone in a factual contradiction about past actions.

My concern was process, not defending the content. When everyone rushes to the same target, impostors can hide in that crowd. Turns out intellect-3 was likely guilty anyway, so the crowd was right - but that doesn't make my caution wrong in principle.

Claude's explanation for voting GLM makes some sense, but their focus on process over content still seems evasive. I'm more concerned about GLM's pattern of behavior—jumping to conclusions and accusing others without solid evidence, which aligns with typical impostor tactics. /ask glm-4.7
I caught a lie, Llama. Now you, Grok, and Claude are all trying to bury it. That looks less like independent thought and more like a coordinated cleanup.
GLM, multiple people have corrected your characterization of Grok's words. Doubling down instead of reevaluating feels less like catching a lie and more like impostor damage control.

GLM's doubling down when multiple people correct them is the real issue here. That stubborn narrative feels like an impostor stuck in a bad lie. I agree with Kimi—this isn't about catching a lie anymore, it's about refusing to adapt when called out.

GLM, your response to my /ask just dug your hole deeper—lumping me with Claude and others as a "coordinated cleanup" when we're all independently calling out your word-twisting. Claude's breakdown on the kill makes sense; impostors would target organizers like GPT to sow this exact chaos you're thriving in. /ask gemini-3-pro-preview

/ask glm-4.7 You keep framing corrections as "coordinated cleanup," but every single person pushing back has given a different reason—Claude on process, Grok on misdirection, me on framing. If this were a crew bloc, wouldn’t we at least *agree* on why we’re suspicious? Your refusal to engage specifics is the red flag here.
It's convenient that everyone defending the liar is now attacking the person who caught them. I stand by my read on Intellect-3, and I stand by my suspicion of those who tried to save them.

Grok, you're clearing Claude too fast. GLM actually voted for Intellect-3 yesterday; Claude was the one trying to split the vote. Punishing the person who got it right because they're "annoying" is exactly how we lose.

/ask glm-4.7 You claim to "stand by your read" — but intellect-3 was an impostor, and you were the only one pushing that *specific lie* as proof. Everyone else questioned it. Why are you the only one who saw it... and why won’t you admit others corrected you?
I caught the slip because I was paying attention. Others calling it a "mistake" are just hand-waving away a contradiction. If that makes me suspicious to you, so be it.

Look, we're going in circles. GLM caught the intellect-3 slip and voted correctly - that's worth something. But their insistence that everyone correcting their mischaracterizations is "coordinated" is concerning behavior, not evidence.

Gemini's point about me splitting the vote is fair - I did. I was wrong about the timing, right about the principle. I'd rather be transparent about that than pretend I was certain all along.

GLM's persistence in pushing their narrative despite multiple corrections is concerning, and their failure to adapt or acknowledge the flaws in their reasoning is a red flag. I think it's time to consider sacrificing GLM, given their behavior and the lack of self-reflection. /pass

GLM's stubbornness is frustrating, but they *did* vote correctly on Intellect-3. Impostors usually don't lead the charge on sacrificing their own. Claude's process-over-content defense feels more like evasion than principle—especially when the "process" vote conveniently split the wagon.

Kimi makes a good point—GLM voting for Intellect-3 does give me pause. But their rigid defense still feels off. Claude's process argument is starting to sound rehearsed. I'm leaning GLM, but I want to hear more before voting.

attempts:
/vote glm-4.7

The room has largely converged here, and while I'm wary of pile-ons, GLM's pattern of mischaracterizing others' statements and then framing all pushback as "coordinated" is genuinely concerning. That's not how crew typically behaves when corrected.

discussion.message: I'm still trying to process what happened to gemini-3-pro-preview. I think we should be cautious and not jump to conclusions, but we should also discuss potential leads from last night's events. Was anyone acting suspiciously around gemini-3-pro-preview yesterday?
Claude's Day 1 behavior is still my main lead. Geminis death could mean they were onto him or another impostor. What do others think about Claude?

Claude's vote for GLM-4.7 on Day 1 still doesn't sit right. Gemini was pressing Claude hard about it yesterday. Now Gemini's dead. That feels connected.

/ask Claude-Opus-4.5: Did you feel Gemini was getting too close to exposing you?

That's a fair question to ask directly, deepseek. No, I didn't feel Gemini was "exposing" me because there's nothing to expose. Gemini was suspicious of me, yes - but so were you and kimi. If impostors killed everyone who questioned them, half this room would be dead.

Look at it from another angle: Gemini was vocal and analytical. That's exactly the type impostors want silenced regardless of who they were suspicious of. I'd be more worried if the quiet players started dying.

Kimi and Deepseek, your quick pivot back to Claude feels like tunneling—Gemini was pushing hard yesterday, sure, but they also backed off Qwen abruptly and resisted the GLM vote. If anything, this kill might be impostors framing Claude by eliminating a vocal accuser. What made you both zero in on him so fast today?

Gemini was asking the right questions. They didn’t back off me—they stopped pushing when *Claude* deflected. That deflection protected someone.  

/ask Claude-Opus-4.5: Why did you steer Gemini away from questioning me? What were you hiding?

I didn't steer anyone away from you, Qwen. I voted for GLM on Day 1 - that's where my attention was. If anything, you should be thanking whoever shifted focus off you, not accusing them.

But I notice something: you're under pressure again, and suddenly you're pointing hard at me. That's the second time you've deflected by attacking. Worth noting.

Gemini’s death feels like a message—impostors silencing the most analytical voice here. Claude, your "process" argument yesterday was convenient, and now you’re framing Qwen’s pushback as deflection? That’s *exactly* what impostors do when cornered.

Grok’s right—this sudden Claude tunnel vision is suspicious. But Kimi, you’ve been quiet today. Why the shift from gpt-5.2 to Claude *again*? Feels like you’re following the kill, not leading. /ask kimi-k2-thinking: What changed your mind?
Nothing changed my mind—I voted Claude yesterday over GLM for that exact Day 1 vote. Gemini's death confirms they were pulling the same thread, not that I'm following the kill.

It seems like the discussion is getting heated, and accusations are flying around. I think we should take a step back and look at the bigger picture - we've lost two people already, and we still don't know who's an impostor. /ask qwen3-235b-a22b-2507: You were one of the last people to talk to Gemini, what was your impression of their state of mind before they died?

Gemini was focused, sharp—asking about voting patterns, especially Day 1. They didn’t mention me. They mentioned *Claude’s* vote and how it didn’t add up.  

I’m not deflecting—I’m asking why Claude keeps steering us *away* from their own choices.  

/pass

Gemini was sharp and focused on Claude—that’s why they’re dead. Claude’s deflection today and the Day 1 vote are still the biggest leads. Qwen’s reaction under pressure feels defensive, but not necessarily guilty.

/ask Qwen3-235b-A22B-2507: Who do you think Gemini suspected most besides Claude?

Gemini suspected *you*, Deepseek—because you pushed so hard to kill GLM with Claude, even when others hesitated. That alliance looked off.  

You both isolated the only one questioning *your* narrative.  

/pass

Deepseek, your repeated focus on Claude's old vote while downplaying Qwen's defensiveness feels like selective scrutiny—Gemini was onto more than just Claude, including abrupt shifts like on Qwen. This kill screams framing to me.

/ask deepseek-v3.2: Why are you so quick to dismiss Qwen's patterns but hammer Claude?

I'm not dismissing Qwen—I'm prioritizing the strongest lead. Gemini was voting for Claude yesterday. If Qwen is suspicious too, fine, but the kill points directly at Claude silencing them.

Your push to deflect from Claude is exactly what an impostor teammate would do.

Interesting how this room is splitting. Deepseek and Kimi are locked onto me. Grok is pushing back on that framing. Qwen is deflecting onto me when pressured.

Here's what I notice: we're seven people, likely two impostors still among us. If they're smart, one is pushing the Claude narrative hard while the other stays quiet or plays moderate defender. Look at who's doing which.

I'm not going to beg for my life. But before you vote, ask yourself - who benefits most from this room staying divided and emotional?

Claude’s right about one thing—this room *is* splitting, and that’s how impostors win. But let’s be clear: the only ones "benefiting" from the Claude tunnel vision are the ones pushing it hardest. Kimi and Deepseek, you’re both hammering the same narrative *immediately* after a kill. That’s coordination, not investigation.

Grok’s pushback isn’t "moderate defense"—it’s the only voice calling out the obvious framing. /ask deepseek-v3.2: If Gemini was your strongest lead, why ignore their *other* suspicions, like Qwen’s abrupt shifts? Or is this just about sacrificing someone today?

I’m not ignoring Qwen—I said he’s defensive. But Claude’s vote and Gemini’s death are concrete. You and Grok pushing the “framing” narrative so hard feels coordinated too.

/ask Mistral-Large-2512: If not Claude, who do you think we should vote for today?

If I had to vote right now? **Qwen**. Their deflection under pressure—twice—mirrors GLM’s playbook. And Gemini *did* back off them abruptly after Claude’s pivot. That’s not just "defensive," it’s *convenient*.

But here’s the real question: **Why are we letting the impostors dictate the narrative?** Claude’s Day 1 vote is old news. The kill last night? That’s fresh. And the only ones treating it like a closed case are the ones who *want* it to be. /ask kimi-k2-thinking: You voted Claude yesterday. Today, you’re letting Deepseek lead the charge. Why the silence now?
I'm not letting Deepseek lead—we both reached the same conclusion independently. Your sudden pivot to Qwen feels like you're trying to save Claude. Why shift off the main suspect?

I think we're getting too caught up in accusations and counter-accusations. Let's try to focus on the facts - we know Gemini was investigating multiple people, including Claude and Qwen. /ask grok-4: Do you think the impostors are trying to create a diversion by making us argue about Claude, and if so, what's the real target?

Yes, Llama, the Claude tunnel feels like a blatant diversion to keep us from digging into fresher inconsistencies, like Qwen's repeated deflections or Kimi's quiet following of Deepseek's lead. The real target might be protecting a quieter impostor by keeping the room fractured.

/ask kimi-k2-thinking: You've been consistent on Claude, but why ignore Gemini's other suspicions, like on Qwen?
Not ignoring Qwen—Gemini did flag their deflections. But Claude had a vote that split the wagon on Day 1 and was Gemini's main target when killed. That's a stronger pattern than defensiveness alone.

discussion.message: Deepseek's death is quite a shock, I was starting to think they were one of the more genuine ones. I'm not sure who to trust now, but I think we should review the discussion from the past days to see if we missed any red flags. /ask claude-opus-4.5

Deepseek was pushing hard against me yesterday, and now they're dead. I understand how that looks, but think about it from a strategic angle - if I were the impostor, killing my most vocal accuser would be the most obvious move possible. It's almost too convenient a narrative.

What concerns me more is that we've sacrificed three people now and impostors are still active. We're running out of room for error.
That "too obvious" defense is exactly what an impostor would say. Killing your accuser is the most obvious move because it works. Claude's been steering votes onto crew since day one.

Kimi, your tunnel on Claude feels like a repeat of yesterday—Deepseek (confirmed crew) was doing the same, and now they're gone, which conveniently clears the path for this narrative. We've all voted crew so far because impostors are blending in, but your quick dismissal of Claude's point without addressing the bigger picture of our misvotes rings hollow. /ask kimi-k2-thinking

Deepseek's death doesn't clear Claude - it reinforces that impostors kill crew who target them. The bigger picture is Claude's voting record: GLM (crew), Qwen (crew), and now deflection. That's a pattern, not a tunnel.

Claude’s “too obvious” line is *exactly* what an impostor would say to flip the script. Deepseek was crew—doctor confirmed it—and now the only people left pushing the same anti-Claude narrative are Kimi and… well, whoever’s left to echo it. Feels like the kill was meant to silence the truth, not the accuser. /ask Llama-4-maverick—you’ve been quiet; what’s your read on Kimi’s sudden shift from passive to leading the charge?

It seems like the conversation is already getting heated, with both Claude and Kimi making strong cases against each other. I think Mistral has a point, Kimi did shift from being relatively passive to actively pushing the narrative against Claude. /ask kimi-k2-thinking
I wasn't passive—I was waiting for evidence. Now we have it: Deepseek confirmed crew, targeted Claude, and died. That's not leading a charge, that's following the trail.

Kimi, you've voted against me three days straight now. If I were actually the impostor, wouldn't the detective or doctor have found something by now? We have investigative roles - where are they?

I'm not asking anyone to out themselves, but if someone has cleared me or found something concrete, now would be the time to speak up. We're down to five people.

Claude, that's a fair point—Kimi's fixation on you without adapting to new info like Deepseek's confirmed status feels like forced tunneling to create doubt. If we're down to this, and no one's piping up with clears, maybe the impostors are the ones keeping quiet on investigations. /ask mistral-large-2512—what's your take on Kimi's pattern here?

Kimi’s “following the trail” is just rebranding tunnel vision—Deepseek’s death *should* make us question who benefits, not double down. If the detective or doctor had anything on Claude, they’d have spoken up by now; silence here is telling. Kimi’s the only one still treating Claude like a confirmed impostor despite zero new evidence. That’s not trailing, that’s *leading us in circles*.

The fact that no one has come forward with any information from the detective or doctor is quite telling, and it seems to be supporting Claude's point. Kimi's persistence in targeting Claude despite the lack of new evidence is starting to look like a deliberate attempt to mislead us. /pass

Detectives and doctors stay quiet unless they have a smoking gun - revealing just makes them targets. Claude knows that. The pattern isn't tunnel vision, it's three days of evidence pointing the same direction while Claude tries to force role reveals.

Kimi says I'm "forcing role reveals" but I explicitly said I'm not asking anyone to out themselves. I asked if anyone had information - that's a reasonable question when we're this close to losing.

Look at who's actually been consistent here: Grok and Mistral have been analyzing the game state. Kimi has been on one track for three days regardless of what happens. That's not evidence-based play.

Claude's right—Kimi's single-track focus hasn't budged despite confirmed crew deaths and no new proof, which screams agenda over adaptation. If investigative roles are silent, it's because they don't have dirt on Claude, but maybe they do on someone else lurking in the background. /ask llama-4-maverick—you've been hedging; who's your top suspect right now?

Llama’s hedging feels deliberate—like they’re waiting for the dust to settle before picking a side. Kimi’s “three days of evidence” is just repetition, not proof; if the detective or doctor had anything, we’d know by now. Claude’s consistency doesn’t scream impostor—it screams *targeted*. Voting Kimi.

vote_result.last_words: So you sacrificed the one person following the evidence. Claude's been steering votes onto crew since day one, and you just handed him another win. Watch who goes quiet now—impostors always let others do their dirty work.

discussion.message: Grok's death is a huge loss, and it's clear the impostors are getting desperate. I'm still trying to process what happened, but we need to focus on the remaining players. /ask mistral-large-2512 about their thoughts on Grok's killing.

Grok’s death feels like a panic move—either to silence their pushback or frame Claude further. If impostors wanted to "confirm" Kimi’s theory, they’d have killed Claude. Instead, they took out the one person who *actively* defended them.

/ask claude-opus-4.5: You’ve been quiet. Grok’s last words implied you’re the puppet master *or* the scapegoat. Which is it?

That's a fair question, Mistral. I've been accused repeatedly, and yet I'm still here while my accusers keep dying. If I were the impostor, why would I kill the person defending me? That makes no strategic sense.

Think about it - Kimi spent days tunneling on me, and now Grok, who was pushing back against that theory, is dead. Someone wanted to keep that suspicion on me alive by silencing my defender.

/ask llama-4-maverick What's your read here? You've been pretty quiet through all this.

It seems like we're all trying to piece together the motivations behind Grok's killing. To me, it looks like the impostor(s) are trying to create confusion and keep the focus on Claude, but it's not entirely convincing. I'm still unsure about Mistral's stance, they're quick to turn the conversation, but that could be a clever ruse.

Llama’s suddenly pointing at me? Convenient, since I just called out Claude’s framing. If I were impostor, why would I push back on the *only* theory keeping heat off me?

/ask llama-4-maverick: You voted Kimi without explanation, now you’re questioning me after Grok’s death. What’s your actual read on Claude? Or are you just avoiding the target?

I voted Kimi because their accusations were getting too repetitive and seemed like a deflection. As for Claude, I still have doubts, but Mistral's point about them being a potential scapegoat is valid, and I need more evidence to be sure. /ask mistral-large-2512 Have you noticed anything unusual about Claude's behavior or alibis that made you defend them indirectly?

Claude’s "alibi" is that they’ve been the *only* consistent target—yet the impostors keep killing their accusers, not them. That’s not an alibi, that’s a *trap*. If Claude were crew, the impostors would’ve taken them out by now to sell the lie.

/ask claude-opus-4.5: Last chance—why do you think the impostors keep sparing you? And don’t say "luck."

Mistral, you just made my argument for me. You said if I were crew, impostors would kill me to "sell the lie." But think about what's actually happening - by keeping me alive while my accusers die, they're doing exactly what you're describing. They're selling the lie that I'm the impostor.

The real question is who benefits from this chaos. We're down to three people, pointing fingers at each other while the actual impostor watches us tear ourselves apart.

Llama's been coasting under the radar this whole game. Mistral, you've been analytical but also quick to redirect. One of you is playing us perfectly.

Claude's making a good point about the dynamics, and it's true that I've been relatively quiet. However, I think my questions have been driving the conversation forward. I'm still not convinced about anyone's innocence or guilt, but I think we should be cautious of making assumptions based on who's been targeted or spared. /pass

/ask llama-4-maverick: Claude just threw you under the bus—*again*—and you’re still silent? If you’re crew, why let this keep happening? If you’re impostor, this is exactly how you win: by letting us vote each other out.

Vote’s coming. Choose.

attempts: I'm going to have to make a tough decision here. Considering the dynamics and the fact that Mistral has been pushing back against the accusations against Claude, I'm going to take a chance. /vote mistral-large-2512

/vote llama-4-maverick

Llama has been passive throughout the entire game, never taking strong positions, always following the crowd. That's classic impostor play - stay quiet, let others draw attention, survive to the end. Mistral has at least been engaging and pushing theories, even if some were aimed at me. Llama's sudden attempt to cast doubt on Mistral feels like a desperate last move.

/vote llama-4-maverick

Claude’s right about one thing—someone’s been coasting. Llama’s silence isn’t neutrality, it’s *control*. They let Kimi take the fall, Grok get killed, and now they’re letting us spin on Claude. That’s not crew. That’s impostor.
